contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox film | name =Yes | image =Yes_(2004)_poster.jpg | caption =Poster for ''Yes'' | director = [[Sally Potter]] | producer = | writer = [[Sally Potter]] | starring =[[Joan Allen]]<br>[[Simon Abkarian]]<br>[[Sam Neill]]<br>[[Gary Lewis (actor)|Gary Lewis]] | music = [[Philip Glass]] (song)<br>[[Tom Waits]] (song)<br>Sally Potter | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = Sony Pictures Classics | released = September 4, 2004 ([[Telluride Film Festival]]) | runtime = 100 min | language = English | budget = Â£1,000,000 (estimated) }} '''''Yes''''' is a 2004 [[film]] written and directed by [[Sally Potter]]. It stars [[Joan Allen]], [[Simon Abkarian]], [[Samantha Bond]], [[Sam Neill]], [[Shirley Henderson]], [[Raymond Waring]], [[Stephanie Leonidas]], and [[Sheila Hancock]]. The film's dialogue is almost entirely in [[iambic pentameter]] and usually rhymes. This artistic choice [[Polarization (politics)|polarized]] [[Film criticism|film critics]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} ==Summary== The film opens as an unnamed [[Irish-American]] [[microbiology|microbiologist]] (Allen) discovers her [[English people|English]] businessman husband Anthony (Neill) is having an affair with their goddaughter's mother. Feeling fragile and alone at an elegant [[London]] dinner party, she meets a [[Lebanese people|Lebanese]] [[Muslim]] chef (Abkarian) who immediately begins seducing her. They soon begin a passionate, torrid affair. He tells her of his past in [[Beirut]], where he was a surgeon who became disillusioned after he saved a man's life moments before he was shot dead. She tells him about her childhood, which began in [[Belfast]] where she was raised by a loving [[Marxist]] aunt before she moved to America. After a racially driven argument in his restaurant's kitchen, the chef is fired. His connection with the microbiologist begins to implode as he questions the foundation for their relationship and cultural attitudes begin to pull them apart. "From [[Elvis]] to [[Eminem]], [[Andy Warhol|Warhol]]'s art," he says, "I know your stories, know your songs by heart. But do you know mine? No, every time, I make the effort, and I learn to rhyme, in your [[English language|English]]. And do you know a word of my language, even one? Have you heard that 'algebra' was an [[Arabic]] man? You've read the [[Bible]]. Have you read the [[Koran]]?" She is called away suddenly to Belfast when her aunt (Hancock) is hospitalized. After the old woman dies, the microbiologist telephones the chef and invites him to travel with her to Cuba, to make the journey her aunt always wanted to make but never did. He, however, has returned to Beirut. She travels alone to Havana where she undergoes an emotional and physical renewal. When she prays to God for some kind of sign that life has meaning, she is interrupted by news that a man is there to see her; it is her lover, the chef, who has suddenly arrived in [[Cuba]] to be with her. The film is punctuated throughout by commentaries and glances from various cleaners and maids who act as a sort of [[Greek chorus]] as they look and speak directly to the camera, most notably the microbiologist's doe-eyed housecleaner (Henderson), who offers various metaphorical bon mots about dirt, germs, and cleanliness and how much they are like the larger world. ==Awards== *2005 [[Brisbane International Film Festival]]: Interfaith Award for Promoting Humanitarian Values{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} *2005 [[Seattle International Film Festival]]: Best Actress ([[Joan Allen]]){{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} ==External links== *[http://www.yesthemovie.com Official site] *[http://greenroom-press.com/clients/Optimum%20Releasing/theatrical/Yes/movies/clip1/yes_clip1_lo.rm Clip from the film] *{{Imdb title|title=Yes|id=0381717}} {{Sally Potter}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yes (Film)}} [[Category:2004 films]] [[Category:Films directed by Sally Potter]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Sony Pictures Classics films]]
